{{hatnote|"Concentration camp" redirects here. For specific contexts see [[Nazi concentration camps]] (World War II) and [[British concentration camps]] (Second Boer War).}} {{for|lists of camps and information on internment actions by country|List of concentration and internment camps}} [[File:Boercamp1.jpg|thumb|[[Boer]] women and children in a British-run concentration camp in South Africa (1900–1902)]] '''Internment''' is the imprisonment or confinement<ref name="Almirante Valdés VS o AV">[http://marinarepublicana.blogspot.com/2011/08/almirante-valdes-vs-o-av.html Almirante Valdés (VS o AV)]</ref> of people, commonly in large groups, without [[trial]]. The term is especially used for the confinement "of enemy citizens in [[war]]time or of [[terrorism]] suspects".<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/internment internment. (n.d.). Collins English Dictionary – Complete & Unabridged 10th Edition. Retrieved November 03, 2014, from Dictionary.com]</ref> Thus, while it can simply mean [[imprisonment]], it tends to refer to preventive confinement, rather than confinement ''after'' having been convicted of some crime. Use of these terms is subject to debate and political sensitivities.<ref name=euph>[http://www.npr.org/blogs/ombudsman/2012/02/10/146691773/euphemisms-concentration-camps-and-the-japanese-internment Euphemisms, Concentration Camps And The Japanese Internment]</ref>
Interned persons may be held in [[prison]]s or in facilities known as [[internment camp]]s. In certain contexts, these may also be known either officially or pejoratively, as [[concentration camp]]s.
Internment also refers to a [[neutral country]]'s practice of detaining [[belligerent]] [[armed forces]] and equipment on its territory during times of war under the [[Hague Convention of 1907]].<ref>{{cite web |date= |title=The Second Hague Convention, 1907 |publisher=Yale.edu |url=http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/lawofwar/hague05.htm |accessdate=1 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121009230811/http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/lawofwar/hague05.htm |archivedate=9 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] restricts the use of internment. Article 9 states that "No one shall be subjected to [[Arbitrary arrest and detention|arbitrary arrest]], [[detention (imprisonment)|detention]] or exile."<ref>[https://www.un.org/en/documents/udhr/index.shtml#a9 Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Article 9], United Nations</ref>
== History and the term "concentration camp" == {{Main article|List of concentration and internment camps}} [[File:Al-Magroon Concentration Camp.jpg|thumb|Ten thousand inmates were kept in [[El Agheila]], one of the [[Italian concentration camps in Libya]] during the [[Italian colonization of Libya]]]] [[Image:Buchenwald Slave Laborers Liberation.jpg|thumb|Jewish slave laborers in the [[Buchenwald concentration camp]] near [[Weimar]], 16 April 1945 (second row from bottom, seventh from left is [[Elie Wiesel]])]]
The ''[[American Heritage Dictionary]]'' defines the term ''concentration camp'' as: "A camp where persons are confined, usually without hearings and typically under harsh conditions, often as a result of their membership in a group the government has identified as suspect."<ref>{{cite web |title=Concentration camp |publisher=American Heritage Dictionary |url=http://ahdictionary.com/word/search.html?q=concentration+camp&submit.x=-664&submit.y=-210 |accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref>
The United States set up concentration camps for [[Cherokee removal|Cherokee]] and other [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] in the 1830s.<ref>James L. Dickerson (2010). ''Inside America's Concentration Camps: Two Centuries of Internment and Torture''. p. 29. Chicago Review Press</ref> In 1864, the U.S. government forced 8,000 [[Navajos]] to walk more than 300 miles at gunpoint from their ancestral homelands in northeastern Arizona and northwestern New Mexico to an internment camp in Bosque Redondo, a desolate tract on the Pecos River in eastern New Mexico.<ref name="Jaimes"/> From 1863 to 1868, the U.S. Military persecuted and imprisoned 9,500 [[Navajo]] and 500 [[Mescalero Apache]]. Living under armed guards, more than 3,500 Navajo and Mescalero Apache men, women, and children died from starvation and disease.<ref name="Jaimes">M. Annette Jaimes (1992). ''The State of Native America: Genocide, Colonization, and Resistance''. p. 34. South End Press</ref> Adolf Hitler admired the U.S. actions toward Native Americans, and in a 1928 speech he praised Americans for having "gunned down the millions of Redskins to a few hundred thousand, and now keep the modest remnant under observation in a cage."<ref>[http://www.timesofisrael.com/american-laws-against-coloreds-influenced-nazi-racial-planners/ "American laws against ‘coloreds’ influenced Nazi racial planners"]. Times of Israel. Retrieved August 31, 2017</ref>
The English term concentration camp was first used in order to refer to the ''reconcentrados'' (reconcentration camps) set up by the [[Spain under the Restoration|Spanish military]] in [[Cuba]] during the [[Ten Years' War]] (1868–78) and the [[Cuban War for Independence]] (1895–98), and similar camps set up by the United States during the [[Philippine–American War]] (1899–1902).<ref name="columbia">{{cite encyclopedia |date=2008 |title=Concentration Camp |work=The Columbia Encyclopedia |edition=Sixth |publisher=Columbia University Press}} </ref>
The term ''concentration camp'' saw wider use during the [[Second Boer War]] (1899–1902), when the [[British concentration camps|British operated such camps]] in South Africa for interning [[Boer]]s.<ref name="columbia"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Documents re camps in Boer War |publisher=sul.stanford.edu |url=http://www-sul.stanford.edu/africa/boers.html |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070609212833/http://www-sul.stanford.edu/africa/boers.html |archivedate=9 June 2007 |df=dmy }}</ref> They built 45 tented camps for Boer internees and 64 for black Africans. Of the 28,000 Boer men captured as prisoners of war, the British sent 25,630 overseas. The vast majority of Boers remaining in the local camps were women and children,<ref name=meredith452456/> over 26,000 of whom died there.<ref name=meredith452456>{{cite book |title=Diamonds, Gold, and War: The British, the Boers, and the Making of South Africa Conditions were reputedly even worse in the camps where black Africans were held, but unlike in the Boer camps, death rates were not recorded in the camps where black Africans were held.|last=Meredith|first=Martin|authorlink=Martin Meredith|year=2007|edition=First|location=New York|publisher=[[PublicAffairs]]|isbn=978-1586484736|pages=452–56}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Boer Wars (2): 1898–1902|series=Men-at-Arms|number=303|last=Knight|first=Ian|year=2000|location=Oxford|publisher=Osprey Publishing|isbn=978-1855326132|p=40}}</ref>
Between 1904 and 1908, the [[German Army (German Empire)|Imperial German Army]] operated concentration camps like the [[Shark Island Concentration Camp]] in [[German South-West Africa]] (now [[Namibia]]) as part of its [[Herero and Namaqua genocide|genocide of the Herero and Namaqua peoples]].
In the late 1930s, over 100,000 defeated or interned personnel of the Spanish Republican armed forces, along with civilians, were held in concentration camps by the government of France, and they included [[Meknassy|Meheri Zabbens]],<ref name="Almirante Valdés VS o AV"/> and the [[Camp de concentration d'Argelès-sur-Mer]] in southern France. Some of them managed to go into exile or went off to join the [[Allies of World War II|armies of the Allies]] in order to fight against the [[Axis powers]],<ref>[http://www.pourlamemoire.com/reportages-tempoignages.php 24 au 26 août 1944 Libération de Paris par les chars... espagnols de la nueve]{{Dead link|date=August 2016}}</ref> while others ended up in [[Nazi concentration camps]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20130528190203/http://www.xtec.cat/iesrovira-forns/documents/EstimadaSisqueta.pdf “Republicans deportats als camps de concentració nazis”]</ref>
During the 20th century, the arbitrary internment of civilians by the state reached its most extreme form with the establishment of the [[Nazi concentration camps]] (1933–45). The Nazi concentration camp system was extensive, with as many as 15,000 camps<ref name="jewishvirtuallibrary1">[https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Holocaust/cclist.html ''Concentration Camp Listing''] Sourced from Van Eck, Ludo ''Le livre des Camps.'' Belgium: Editions Kritak; and Gilbert, Martin ''Atlas of the Holocaust.'' New York: William Morrow 1993 {{ISBN|0-688-12364-3}}. In this on-line site are the names of 149 camps and 814 subcamps, organized by country.</ref> and at least 715,000 simultaneous internees.<ref>{{cite book | last = Evans | first = Richard J.| title = The Third Reich in Power | year = 2005 | publisher = Penguin Group | location = New York | isbn = 978-0-14-303790-3}}</ref> The total number of casualties in these camps is difficult to determine, but the conscious policy of [[extermination through labor]] in at least some of the camps ensured that the inmates would die of starvation, untreated disease and summary executions.<ref name="Marek Przybyszewski">Marek Przybyszewski, [https://web.archive.org/web/20101022004220/http://www.historia.terramail.pl/opracowania/nowozytna/zamek_centrum_administracji.html IBH Opracowania – Działdowo jako centrum administracyjne ziemi sasińskiej (Działdowo as centre of local administration).] Internet Archive, 22 October 2010.</ref> Moreover, Nazi Germany established six [[extermination camp]]s, specifically designed to kill millions, primarily by [[Extermination camp#Gassing|gassing]].<ref name="Gellately2001">{{cite book |author1=Robert Gellately |author2=Nathan Stoltzfus |title=Social Outsiders in Nazi Germany |year=2001 |publisher=Princeton University Press |isbn=978-0-691-08684-2 |page=216 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1toqgWg8ROUC&q=forced+labor#v=snippet&q=forced%20labor&f=false }}</ref><ref>Anne Applebaum, [http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/2001/oct/18/a-history-of-horror/ A History of Horror], Review of "Le Siècle des camps" by Joël Kotek and Pierre Rigoulot, [[The New York Review of Books]], 18 October 2001</ref>
As a result, some say that today the term "concentration camp" may be conflated with the concept of "extermination camp" and historians debate whether the term "concentration camp" or "internment camp" should be used in order to describe other examples of civilian internment, such as the [[United States]] government's [[internment of Japanese Americans]] during World War II,<ref name=euph/> and the Australian government's [[Australian immigration detention facilities|immigrant detention facilities]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/comment/our-detention-centres-are-intentionally-cruel-and-must-be-closed-20160504-golr04.html|title=Our detention centres are concentration camps and must be closed|first=Stephen|last=Charles|date=4 May 2016|publisher=|via=The Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref>
